head.title: How Jews Recall A Collective Horror

hedline.hl1: How Jews Recall A Collective Horror

block.p: Re ''More Than One Way to Remember the Holocaust'' (Jerusalem Journal, May 3): Orthodox Jews who choose to memorialize the Holocaust on the day of collective Jewish mourning known as Tisha B'Av rather than on the State of Israel-inspired Holocaust Remembrance Day are in no way diminishing the horror of the event.

Re ''More Than One Way to Remember the Holocaust'' (Jerusalem Journal, May 3): Orthodox Jews who choose to memorialize the Holocaust on the day of collective Jewish mourning known as Tisha B'Av rather than on the State of Israel-inspired Holocaust Remembrance Day are in no way diminishing the horror of the event.

Quite the contrary, haredim are deeply conscious of the Holocaust and since the immediate postwar years have tirelessly been rebuilding the Jewish communities and Jewish scholarship that were decimated.

Moreover, by mourning the horrific event on Tisha B'Av, they thereby empower it with the collective memory of every other national catastrophe that the Jewish people have suffered over the course of history.
(Rabbi) AVI SHAFRAN Director of Public Affairs Agudath Israel of America New York, May 3, 2000
